title: Publications
text: My research focuses on Science of Science, Complex Networks, and Academic Career Development. I use data-driven approaches to understand how mentorship, team size, and network structures affect scientific survival and success in the life-course perspective. Recently, my research has also expanded to include the evolution of cross-disciplinary knowledge.

title: About
text:
Our group is committed to building a respectful, collaborative, and intellectually open research environment. We believe that high-quality research is best achieved in a culture where ideas can be discussed openly and where individuals are treated with mutual respect.
We emphasize equality and collegiality among faculty, students, and peers. Academic discussions within the group are encouraged to be constructive and inclusive, and members are supported in developing their own perspectives and academic identities. We value collaboration over hierarchy and encourage independent thinking at all career stages.
We also place strong emphasis on work–life balance. We believe that sustainable research progress comes from long-term well-being rather than short-term overwork. Group members are encouraged to manage their time responsibly, maintain healthy boundaries between research and personal life, and pursue research in a way that is both ambitious and sustainable.
Academically, the group aims to maintain both international and domestic competitiveness. Our research focuses on addressing frontier scientific questions while remaining grounded in real-world relevance. We strive to bridge theory, data, and practice, contributing to the understanding of scientific systems and innovation processes.
Overall, our goal is to foster a research culture that is rigorous but humane, ambitious but sustainable, and supportive of students’ growth into independent researchers.

I will be a tenure-track assistant professor at the Data Management Innovation Research Center, Nanjing University, Suzhou Campus. Previously, I was a postdoctoral researcher in the Department of Statistics and Data Science, Southern University of Science and Technology (July 2023–December 2025). My research expertise lies in Science of Science, Complex Networks, and Scientometrics. I am particularly interested in the career development paths of young scholars and the mechanisms of academic mentorship.
My recent research, published in Nature Human Behaviour, explores how academic group size influences mentee’s scientific career. This work has been highlighted by Nature News: “How a PhD student’s lab size affects their chance of future academic success”.




[2026.01] Since 2026.01, I have been serving as an independent Principal Investigator (PI) at Nanjing University.
[2025.03] Our work on mentorship published in Nature Human Behaviour is featured by Nature News!

title: Join Us
text:
We are currently looking for highly motivated Master’s and Ph.D. students to join our research group starting in 2027.

Pre-Master and Pre-Doctoral Opportunities
Students planning to apply for the 2027 Master’s or Ph.D. programs are welcome to contact me in advance to explore opportunities to join the group as pre-master’s or pre-doctoral researchers.
During the pre-master / pre-doctoral period, students will: - Participate in ongoing research projects - Receive close research mentorship and training - Gain hands-on experience with real-world research data - Be supported in preparing for graduate applications - Work in a respectful and supportive research environment
In addition, students may have opportunities to engage in international academic exchange and collaboration, including potential interactions with research partners in Europe, the United States, and Hong Kong, depending on project needs and individual interests.
Appropriate research stipends will be provided based on individual engagement and project involvement.


Research Directions
Our group conducts interdisciplinary research at the intersection of Science of Science, Complex Networks, and Academic Career Development. We use large-scale data and computational methods to study how mentorship, collaboration structures, and team dynamics shape scientific careers over the life course.
In addition, we are increasingly interested in artificial intelligence–driven approaches to understanding research network dynamics and knowledge evolution, including: - The role of AI in shaping cross-disciplinary knowledge creation - Network dynamics of scientific collaboration and authorship - The evolution of research topics and ideas across disciplines - Data-driven modeling of scientific discovery and innovation processes
Students with interests in AI for science, network science, computational social science, or data-driven studies of knowledge systems are especially encouraged to apply.


Prospective Master’s and Ph.D. Students (2027 Intake)
Applicants with a strong background in mathematics, statistics, computer science, physics, data science, or related fields will be well suited for the group. Prior experience with Python, SQL, machine learning, or large-scale data analysis is a plus, but not strictly required.


How to Apply
If you are interested, please send an email to
yanmeng0608@outlook.com
with: - A brief CV - Academic transcripts (if available) - A short description of your research interests and background
Early contact is strongly encouraged.

We aim to build a research environment that is respectful, collaborative, and intellectually open, supports work–life balance, and encourages students to grow into independent researchers. We welcome students who are curious, self-motivated, and eager to explore data-driven research questions at the frontier of science.
